title: Mum says 'every loving parent' should smack their child for proper discipline
text:

A mum has sparked an intense debate by claiming "every loving parent" should smack their children.

Journalist Claire Muldoon clashed with another mum on This Morning when they appeared as guests on the show to discuss Scotland's smacking ban.

It has become the first part of the UK to outlaw the smacking of kids as pressure grows to widen the ban to England and Northern Ireland, while Wales begins drawing up a similar law.

The Scottish mum criticised the change, saying: "I definitely think it is Big Brother honing in on this and every loving parent would use some form of physical chastisement - not always but if it's suitable."

Claire continued: “This whole thing stems from love. If you had a friend who was doing something that was harming themselves - you would hope that a friend would say look let's be honest your behaviour is wrong.”

(Image: ITV)

Mum-of-two and journalist Rebecca Wilcox disagreed with her, saying she doesn't believe in smacking children.

She said she felt "awful" about once hitting her four-year-old son when he spilt water on her laptop, calling the moment her "biggest guilt as a mum."

Rebecca said it left her feeling like a "hypocrite": "I remember it was all about my loss of control... yeah, he was misbehaving. Yes, he was doing something wrong.

"But I'm the adult. I should know better. I'm constantly saying 'don't hit your brother, don't hit your friends, don't hit me.' What am I doing?"

(Image: ITV)

(Image: Getty Images)

When she begins saying she saw "fear" in her son's eyes and conceded there was "an effect" during the debate, Claire rolls her eyes and nods.

The show's host Ruth Langsford points out that had she hit her son in Scotland under the new laws she could be prosecuted for the act.

Claire adds: "You'd not be sitting here, today, Rebecca, if that was the case."

Rebecca responds that she didn't think it would go that far- saying the law would give Child Protection workers tools to intervene and educate parents against corporal punishment.

"I feel so bad about it I probably should have been prosecuted. That little boy had done nothing wrong. He had tipped a glass of water over my laptop."

(Image: ITV)

Langsford then agreed with Rebecca, adding that children are taught that physical violence is wrong and pointed out if one adult slapped another in the supermarket it would be an assault under law.

The segment sparked debate on Twitter , as viewers argued over their points of view on whether smacking was an effective parenting strategy, or just outright wrong.

Some claimed they were smacked as children and it didn't affect them in later life.

Others argued that they were able to discipline their children using their voice and leading by example.

(Image: Getty Images)

Some viewers said they learned to fear smacking as children and behaved better as a result.

One smacking critic argued if her husband hit her it would be labelled domestic abuse and questioned why hitting a child would be treated any differently.

Another said parents were supposed to be role models to their children and that physical discilpline taught them it is OK to hit people to make a point.

Pressure is growing on Westminster to expand Scotland's contentious new law to the rest of the UK.

The Scottish Parliament earlier this week outlawed all physical punishment against under-16s, giving children the same protection from assault as adults.

A defence of "reasonable chastisement" or "justifiable assault" for physical force used as a form of discipline on children was removed.

It is now the 58th country in the world to outlaw smacking, and Wales is now also drawing up similar legislation which passed its first reading in the Welsh assembly last month.

If Wales bans smacking too, it would leave only children in England and Northern Ireland unprotected.

Last year the Association of Educational Psychologists said smacking is harmful to children’s mental health.

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

The children's rights charity NSPCC is also against smacking and says it should be banned throughout the UK because it violates children's rights to be free from physical force or violence.

The Scottish law uses the same definition of physical punishment used by the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child.

It includes smacking, slapping and smacking with a hand or an implement, as well as kicking, shaking or throwing children, scratching, pinching, biting, pulling hair or boxing ears, forcing children to stay in uncomfortable positions, burning, scalding or forced ingestion.
description: Journalist Claire Muldoon defended physical discipline on This Morning as Scotland becomes the first part of the UK to ban smacking
